physDesc.p: This letter is 3 pages long. It is typed on blank paper with the words “Little Review” written in pencil at the top.

div.p: I should have answered your very nice note sooner. Thank you for what you say about my poems. I quite agree with you that Mille. Carret’s criticism does not bite. May I refer you to one that does by Mr. Fletcher to be published in the April “Poetry”.

You remember that I was going to write an article on “The Poetry Book Shop” to soothe Harold Munro’s ruffled feelings. Now in looking through the things he sent me, I find that I have hardly enough data to go on, so I cabled him to send me some more. I also took a wild and unauthorized step by saying in my cable that I was going to put the article into your May number; so will you be an angel and print it then, as I am beginning to feel a little guilty about not having sent it to you before, but the truth is that I have been so busy getting out our Anthology and writing and delivering a course of six lectures on French Poetry that I have sometimes had to work fifteen
hours a day and this Poetry Book Shop article just had to wait. If he does not send me the data, I will just go ahead and do the best I can with a short appreciation, but I should like to have something that would be a sort of history and appreciation in one.

Let me tell you how much I enjoy your magazine. I think it gets better and better with every number, and it is the only magazine which I ever really read. I do not have time to read magazines as a rule, but yours is so full of interest, so new and up-to-date, to unprejudiced and full of life that I simply look forward to the coming of each number with the greatest impatience. I thought Mr. Comfort’s letter in the last number very good and very true. Perhaps you are right to refuse my offer, although in spite of being “businesslike” I am so much in sympathy with everything you are trying to do that I do not think you would have found me quite the fish you imagine. Still, as I say, perhaps you are right, but whatever happens do not let your magazine stop, for we need it and I think the world needs it. All this, of course, is not for publication, merely for private ear and
your heart. And, by the way, I agreed with everything you said about Mrs. Ellis’s lecture, not that I have heard her lecture, but on general principles, I mean.

By the way, who are you going to have review our “Anthology”? It ought to be somebody with sympathy for our aims and an understanding of new departures. I think it ought to be reviewed soon and reviewed at considerable length, for I cannot help feeling that in fifty years it will be rather an important volume. It may be conceited of me to believe so firmly in our little group, but I do. All of the poets in it may not pull through to immortality, but I think some of them will. Have you any opinion as to who might review it?
